Award.AwardTitle: Science Scholarship Program at Lyman Briggs College Phase 2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is awarding a set of three-year scholarships for at least 29 talented and financially needy students at Lyman Briggs College (LBC), a residential science college at Michigan State University (MSU). Half the recipients are recruited from the incoming class students who plan to pursue a natural sciences degree. The other half are recruited from within the MSU undeclared majors. This project uses scholarship money to foster a greater respect and desire to pursue science careers within this cadre of students. The scholars participate in seminar courses that focus on helping students understand the entire scientific enterprise spanning basic research, to dissemination, to graduate school options. Because LCB is a residence college, scholarship recipients develop into a cohesive cohort by living together and taking these seminar courses. Further, scholars are encouraged to complete undergraduate research as a portion of their program and to become learning assistants which may encourage them to pursue a career in science education. In addition, the project involves the LCB alumni base to develop internship opportunities for scholarship recipients. The intellectual value of this program is the creation of a series of seminar courses designed to recruit students into the sciences and explicitly highlight the breadth of possibilities in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created three-year scholarships for two cohorts of financially-needy and academically talented science students interested in STEM fields during their 2nd-4th year at Michigan State University. Students could receive $3000 in the first year of the program, $6000 in the second, and $9000 in the third. The cohorts had 15 and 14 students respectively; in total, the program supported 37 scholars as some students lost financial eligibility over the three-year program, did not maintain the requisite GPA, or decided to pursue a non-STEM career. Of the supported students, 35/37 will complete their undergraduate degree with a STEM major at the conclusion of the Spring 2017 semester.  Within the program, 25 of the students were female, 13 were first generation college students, and 16 were Pell Grant eligible, which indicates the greatest level of financial need.

Each cohort of students completed three seminar courses with a single faculty mentor.  The first two focused on career exploration and understanding the entire scientific endeavor. The last was a capstone course with a major theme.  The first cohort focused on scientific communication and outreach and the second cohort focused on communication and diversity in STEM. Both courses helped the scholars explore how they can more effectively share their scientific knowledge in whatever careers they pursue and recognize the value that others bring to the field. The students under the guidance of the faculty cohort mentors primarily organized the courses. Finally, our scholars are encouraged to complete undergraduate research as a portion of this program, either through research with university faculty, via internship experiences fostered by college alumni, or with an external organization.

Every semester the students met with an academic advisor to ensure continual growth and progress toward a STEM career. Each year, the students also completed interviews during which they reflected on their experiences over the previous year. They discussed how their understanding and attitudes toward science had changed and what events shaped any changes.  These interviews, along with annual, reflective career essays provided qualitative data on the undergraduate STEM student experience.  The data from these interviews are being analyzed to better understand questions about the impact of the increasing scholarship value, the methods by which the scholar’s cohort peers influenced them, and the value and drawbacks of creating a cohort of students with a wide range of STEM majors.  Preliminary results have been presented at three different local and national meetings.
